reviews.review_msg: One of the most detailed, clear and caring profs at the entire university. He actually wants you to succeed and even better, wants to help you do it. Do not expect a prof who throws out a guideline and calls it a day. He walks you through what you need to know so specifically that it makes it feel easy to succeed.

Great prof! If you attend lectures and study what is on the slides, you will do fine on the tests. Assignments are marked by your TA (or at least mine were), so how tough stuff is graded really depends on them. Overall, it was a very straightforward and relatively easy course.

Great prof! The course material for CMNS201w is pretty dry, but the prof engages the content in interesting ways and is very involved with the labs and tutorials. Easily approachable and down-to-earth professor.
Be aware of confusion. The class needs to be structured better.
HE IS AMAZING! Chris is so helpful and personable, he is there to help literally at any time. I can't say enough about this prof, you have to take a course with him!

He was totally understanding of COVID situations and made sure everyone gets bonus points etc. Would definitely take his course in the future if I can, and one of the most understanding prof Ive met in SFU. Lecture videos were short, but summarized the key points for each chapter.
Great professor,  so organized and straight to the point

He's a nice guy but he was not able to teach the materials properly. It's very crucial because this is a 4 credit and Q course, so the fact that he rushes his lectures and makes us rely on the textbook makes it so much harder. Avoid him for this particular CMNS course. His quizzes are also worth so much, it's ridiculous.

He was very nice and caring towards his students. The course was supposed to be in-person but got moved to online so there was no final exam. We had 3 main assignments, lab and tutorial participation, and weekly lecture reviews.

Ahmed tends to rush through his lecture slides and does not give reasonable time for us to write notes. I learn more from reading the textbook than listening to his lectures because he briefly skims over the concepts and does not go in depth at all. There are 4 quizzes and 1 final quiz and 3 assignments so the workload is quite heavy.
